title: 110_hr3059
content: Increased average fuel economy standards. Increased average fuel economy standards for non-passenger automobiles to a minimum of 27.5 miles per gallon for model year 2022 and subsequent years. Regulations for passenger automobiles must be set 18 months before each model year. The Secretary sets average fuel economy standards for passenger automobiles each model year, ensuring a minimum of 35 miles per gallon for model year 2022 and beyond. Different standards may apply based on vehicle attributes. The average fuel economy standard for passenger automobiles is set by the Secretary each model year, with a minimum of 35 miles per gallon for model year 2022 and beyond. An alternative minimum standard applies to domestically manufactured passenger automobiles, set at either 27.5 miles per gallon or 92 percent of the average fuel economy projected by the Secretary for all manufacturers in that model year. This standard only applies if the average fuel economy standard for passenger automobiles based on vehicle attributes does not include transferred credits. The Secretary sets the average fuel economy standard for passenger automobiles each model year. Manufacturers can choose to comply with an attribute-based standard or a single corporate average fuel economy level. The amendments made by this section will take effect upon the enactment of the Act, with a transition period for passenger automobiles. The enactment of this Act establishes standards for passenger automobiles under section 32902(b) of title 49, United States Code. Technical and conforming amendments are made to Chapter 329 of title 49, including defining a "non-passenger automobile" and expanding the subsections under section 32902(g). The Act establishes standards for passenger automobiles under section 32902(b) of title 49, United States Code. Technical amendments are made to Chapter 329, including expanding subsections and defining "non-passenger automobiles." The Act makes technical amendments to Chapter 329 of title 49, US Code, including defining "non-passenger automobiles" and updating subsections. The Act makes technical amendments to Chapter 329 of title 49, US Code, including defining "non-passenger automobiles" and updating subsections related to credit transferring within a manufacturer's fleet. The Act amends Section 32903 of title 49, US Code to establish a corporate average fuel economy credit transferring program for manufacturers to transfer credits within their fleet to comply with fuel economy standards. Transferred credits can increase a compliance category by 1.0 mile per gallon in a single model year. Transfers to certain categories are limited based on the manufacturer's fleet fuel economy level. The Act establishes a corporate average fuel economy credit transferring program for manufacturers to transfer credits within their fleet to comply with fuel economy standards. Transferred credits can increase a compliance category by 1.0 mile per gallon in a single model year, with limitations on transfers based on the manufacturer's fleet fuel economy level. Credits can only be transferred if earned in model year 2010 or later. The Secretary of Transportation will partner with industry groups to create a public education campaign on fuel conservation for drivers. The campaign will use various methods to reach a wide audience and the Secretary will provide up to 50% of the campaign's cost, with the option to accept private funds. Appropriations will be made as needed for this program.
